SUPPORT?

One thing that was especially
noticeable at the football game last
Saturday was the utter lack of any
organized cheering among the Hopkins supporters. It was a very disheartening state of affairs for any'pne who really cared about the
"Black and Blue" down there on
the field. It was true that neither
team displayed any appreciable
amount £>f brilliant playing and that
at times, the game became slow and
uninteresting. Nevertheless, that
did not excuse the Jay rooters from
letting the "pig-skin carriers" know
that they were in the stands, and
that they were pulling for them.
This is the first year, to our
knowledge, that the Blue Jay football team has played a game on its
home ground without at least one
cheer leader to head the rooters in
a few yells. The reason for this we
do not know, but we think that such
a situation should not be allowed
to arise again.
We realize that since the abolition
of all freshmen regulation two years
ago, the yearlings are given a free
hand and are no longer required to
form in line in front of Gilman
Hall before the game and march up
Charles Street and into Homewood
Field preceeded by the Johns Hopkins Band. In those days the teams
were always guaranteed a certain
amount of support, namely that
given it by the frosh rooters.
Under our present system, some
of the freshmen take enough in·
terest in the teams to come out and
lend their support to the 'leven,
others, not quite so enthusiastic as
the first mentioned, come to the
games, but do not so much as open
their mouths to let out a single peep
during the whole game, while the
remainder think that they have
many other things more important
to do and stay away entirely-these
latter ones, we feel moved to say,
have a very poor and unenviable
spirit.
We hope that these few words
that we have printed above will
touch the pride and latent spirits of
some few individuals and that they
will be inspired to literally "come
out to Homewood and see Johnny
Hopkins play!"

Successor To Dr. Bull
Being Sought

A committee is now endeavoring
to select a successor to Dr. Carroll
G. Bull, late professor of immunology at the School of Hygiene and
Public Health, who died last May.
The selection is to be ratified by
the Board of Trustees.

with a great deal of favor. Plans
for a similar attraction at tomorrow's dance are in mind.

Group Appointed Last March To Do Research Work
Here; New Fellowship Obtained
From Tobacco Company
Twelve Fellows in Chemistry, appointed last March for the term
i931-32, began research work this
week at the Johns Hopkins University. This group brings the total
of Fellows in Chemistry to 32,
twenty of which were awarded fellowships during 1929 and 1930.
The new group includes:
C. Gerald Albert. New Haven,
Conn., of Yale University; Philip
G. Ackerman, Corvallis, Oregon, of
Oregon State Agricultural College;
R. Keith Blakely, Albuquerque, New
Mexico, of University of New Mexico; Kenneth W. Brighton, Salt
Lake City, Utah, of University of
Utah; Harold G. Burman, Mitchell,
South Dakota, of Dakota Wesleyan
University; William P . Hall, Los
Angeles, California, of Occidental
College; James L. Nauman, Mt.
Vernon, Iowa, of Cornell College;
Charles C. Rainey. of Emory University, Virgin¥!; A. C.. Lippert,
Champaign, Ill. ; Robert J. Myers,
Craighton University, . Nebraska;
Clayton W. Terry, North Dakota; L.
A. Burroughs, Washington College,
Missouri.

Inaugurated 1929

Inaugurated in the fall of 1929,
the fellowship plan in the department of chemistry at the Johns
Hopkins has become national and
international in scope. For a study
in the selection and education of
prospective leaders in the field of
chemistry, the department at Homewood has planned a definite p.rogram.
Thirty-one fellowships to support
specially chosen students in graduate'Study in the science have been
donated by individuals and corporations.

SUPPORT?

One thing that was especially
noticeable at the football game last
Saturday was the utter lack of any
organized cheering among the Hopkins supporters. It was a very disheartening state of affairs for any'pne who really cared about the
"Black and Blue" down there on
the field. It was true that neither
team displayed any appreciable
amount £>f brilliant playing and that
at times, the game became slow and
uninteresting. Nevertheless, that
did not excuse the Jay rooters from
letting the "pig-skin carriers" know
that they were in the stands, and
that they were pulling for them.
This is the first year, to our
knowledge, that the Blue Jay football team has played a game on its
home ground without at least one
cheer leader to head the rooters in
a few yells. The reason for this we
do not know, but we think that such
a situation should not be allowed
to arise again.
We realize that since the abolition
of all freshmen regulation two years
ago, the yearlings are given a free
hand and are no longer required to
form in line in front of Gilman
Hall before the game and march up
Charles Street and into Homewood
Field preceeded by the Johns Hopkins Band. In those days the teams
were always guaranteed a certain
amount of support, namely that
given it by the frosh rooters.
Under our present system, some
of the freshmen take enough in·
terest in the teams to come out and
lend their support to the 'leven,
others, not quite so enthusiastic as
the first mentioned, come to the
games, but do not so much as open
their mouths to let out a single peep
during the whole game, while the
remainder think that they have
many other things more important
to do and stay away entirely-these
latter ones, we feel moved to say,
have a very poor and unenviable
spirit.
We hope that these few words
that we have printed above will
touch the pride and latent spirits of
some few individuals and that they
will be inspired to literally "come
out to Homewood and see Johnny
Hopkins play!"

Successor To Dr. Bull
Being Sought

A committee is now endeavoring
to select a successor to Dr. Carroll
G. Bull, late professor of immunology at the School of Hygiene and
Public Health, who died last May.
The selection is to be ratified by
the Board of Trustees.

Twelve New Fellows In Chem.
Begin Work At Johns Hopkins
Group Appointed Last March To Do Research Work
Here; New Fellowship Obtained
From Tobacco Company
Twelve Fellows in Chemistry, appointed last March for the term
i931-32, began research work this
week at the Johns Hopkins University. This group brings the total
of Fellows in Chemistry to 32,
twenty of which were awarded fellowships during 1929 and 1930.
The new group includes:
C. Gerald Albert. New Haven,
Conn., of Yale University; Philip
G. Ackerman, Corvallis, Oregon, of
Oregon State Agricultural College;
R. Keith Blakely, Albuquerque, New
Mexico, of University of New Mexico; Kenneth W. Brighton, Salt
Lake City, Utah, of University of
Utah; Harold G. Burman, Mitchell,
South Dakota, of Dakota Wesleyan
University; William P . Hall, Los
Angeles, California, of Occidental
College; James L. Nauman, Mt.
Vernon, Iowa, of Cornell College;
Charles C. Rainey. of Emory University, Virgin¥!; A. C.. Lippert,
Champaign, Ill. ; Robert J. Myers,
Craighton University, . Nebraska;
Clayton W. Terry, North Dakota; L.
A. Burroughs, Washington College,
Missouri.

Inaugurated 1929

Inaugurated in the fall of 1929,
the fellowship plan in the department of chemistry at the Johns
Hopkins has become national and
international in scope. For a study
in the selection and education of
prospective leaders in the field of
chemistry, the department at Homewood has planned a definite p.rogram.
Thirty-one fellowships to support
specially chosen students in graduate'Study in the science have been
donated by individuals and corporations.
